The Act may be cited as the "America's Border Security Act of 2007" and includes provisions related to technological assets. The "America's Border Security Act of 2007" mandates increased use of Department of Defense equipment like UAVs and radars to aid in surveillance at US borders to curb illegal immigration. The "America's Border Security Act of 2007" requires the use of surveillance equipment by the Department of Defense to assist in monitoring the international land borders of the United States to prevent illegal immigration. Within 6 months of the Act's enactment, a report must be submitted to Congress detailing the current use of Defense equipment for border surveillance and assessing risks to citizens. The Department of Defense uses equipment to assist the Secretary of Homeland Security in surveilling the US international land borders and assessing associated risks. The plan includes increasing the use of Defense equipment for surveillance activities and providing equipment and support by the Secretary of Defense. During a 1-year period, the Secretary of Homeland Security will conduct a pilot program using unmanned aerial vehicles for border surveillance along the US-Canada international border. The plan includes utilizing Department of Defense equipment to assist in surveillance activities and providing support from the Secretary of Defense. The Secretary of Homeland Security will conduct a pilot program using unmanned aerial vehicles for border surveillance along the US-Canada international border. Appropriations are authorized for fiscal years 2008 through 2012 to carry out the program, with no impact on the prohibition of using the Army or Air Force as a posse comitatus. SEC. 3. INFRASTRUCTURE.

The Secretary of Homeland Security is authorized to construct roads, acquire barriers, and facilities to control the US international borders. Quarterly progress reports to Congress are required, and appropriations are authorized for fiscal years 2008 through 2012. SEC. 4. PORTS OF ENTRY. The Secretary of Homeland Security can build new ports of entry along US borders and improve existing ones. SEC. 5. SECURE COMMUNICATION. The Secretary of Homeland Security is required to develop a plan to enhance satellite communications for clear and secure 2-way communication among Border Patrol agents, their stations, residents in remote areas along international borders, and other border security agencies. The Secretary of Homeland Security is mandated to improve satellite communications for Border Patrol agents, their stations, and residents in remote areas along international borders, as well as other border security agencies. This includes enhancing communication between Border Patrol agents and residents in remote areas, and between border security agencies and State, local, and tribal law enforcement agencies. SEC. 6. UNMANNED AERIAL VEHICLES. The Secretary of Homeland Security is required to acquire and maintain at least 5 unmanned aerial vehicles and related equipment for patrolling the US international borders. This includes additional sensors, critical spares, satellite command and control, and other necessary operational support equipment. Authorization of appropriations is provided for fiscal years 2008 and 2009 to fund these activities. Authorization of appropriations is provided for fiscal years 2008 and 2009 to fund the acquisition and maintenance of unmanned aerial vehicles for patrolling US international borders. Amounts appropriated are authorized to remain available until expended. SEC. 7. SURVEILLANCE TECHNOLOGIES PROGRAMS. The Secretary of Homeland Security is required to develop and implement an aerial surveillance program using unmanned aerial vehicles to enhance border security between the United States and Canada as part of the surveillance technologies programs. The Secretary of Homeland Security is mandated to fully integrate aerial surveillance technologies, including unmanned aerial vehicles, to enhance border security along the international borders of the United States with Canada and Mexico. The program aims to continuously monitor every mile of these borders, considering various surveillance technologies and assessing their feasibility and advisability. The Secretary of Homeland Security will consider aerial surveillance technologies, assess their feasibility for addressing border threats, consult with the Secretary of Defense on deployment along international borders. The Secretary of Homeland Security will consult with the Secretary of Defense on deploying technologies along international borders and with the FAA on airspace coordination for the aerial surveillance program. The aerial surveillance program developed under this subsection will use various technologies in different terrains near international borders to assess their effectiveness. During fiscal year 2008, the Secretary of Homeland Security is required to increase the number of full-time agents and support staff in the Bureau of Immigration and Customs Enforcement by 400, and the number of full-time inspectors and support staff in the Bureau of Customs and Border Protection by 600. The Secretary is authorized to waive any limitation on the number of full-time equivalent positions. The Secretary of Homeland Security is authorized to increase the number of full-time agents and support staff in the Bureau of Immigration and Customs Enforcement by 400, and inspectors and support staff in the Bureau of Customs and Border Protection by 600. The Secretary can waive any limitation on full-time equivalent personnel. Additionally, ongoing training is required for Department of Homeland Security personnel to utilize new technologies and maintain acceptable proficiency levels for border protection. SEC. 9. NATIONAL BORDER SECURITY PLAN. The Secretary of Homeland Security must prepare and submit a National Border Security Plan to Congress by January 31 each year. The plan should include a vulnerability assessment of each port of entry and consultation with relevant agencies and entities involved in international trade across the northern and southern borders. The National Border Security Plan must include a vulnerability assessment of each port of entry on the northern and southern borders. The plan may establish port security coordinators to assist with assessments and provide support. The National Border Security Plan requires a vulnerability assessment at each port of entry on the northern and southern borders. Port security coordinators may be established to assist with assessments and provide support.
